com.pb.sawdust.util.concurrent

Class DnCRecursiveTask<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.concurrent.ForkJoinTask<V>
      • java.util.concurrent.RecursiveTask<T>
        • com.pb.sawdust.util.concurrent.DnCRecursiveTask<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The type returned by this task.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.util.concurrent.Future<T>

    public abstract class DnCRecursiveTask<T>
extends java.util.concurrent.RecursiveTask<T>
    The DnCRecursiveTask provides a framework for "divide-and-conquer" RecursiveTasks. A divide-and-conquer task is recursively split in half as seperate tasks (within a ForkJoinPool) until some criterion is reached, at which point the sub-tasks are executed and their results combined. The criterion should generally use the static getSurplusQueuedTaskCount() method inherited from the RecursiveTask class.

    In order to work correctly, the two constructors in this class must be used in a specific manner. The constructor taking two long arguments is intended for use as the (super) constructor of the instance passed to the ForkJoinPool. The other constructor should be invoked (through super calls) in the implementation of the getNextTask(long, long, DnCRecursiveTask) method.

    To make this more concrete, the following presents an example implementation for an task which takes an array of doubles and returns the sum of its squares. 

    
     public class ArraySquareSum extends DnCRecursiveTask<Double> {
         private final double[] array;

         public ArraySquareSum(double[] array) {
             super(0,array.length);
             this.array = array;
         }

         private ArraySquareSum(double[] array, long start, long length, DnCRecursiveTask<Double> next) {
             super(start,length,next);
             this.array = array;
         }

         protected Double computeTask(long start, long length) {
             long end = start + length;
             double sum = 0.0;
             for (long i = start; i < end; i++)
                 sum += array[i]*array[i];
             return sum;
         }

         protected DnCRecursiveTask<Double> getNextTask(long start, long length, DnCRecursiveTask<Double> next) {
             return new ArraySquareSum(array,start,length,next);
         }

         protected boolean continueDividing(long newLength) {
             return getSurplusQueuedTaskCount() < 3;
         }

         protected T joinResults(T currentResult, T nextResult) {
             return currentResult + nextResult;
         }
     }

                              long length,
                              DnCRecursiveTask<T> next)
        Get the next (sub-)task resulting from a division. This method should return an instance of the subclass which uses the DnCRecursiveTask(long, long, DnCRecursiveTask) constructor as its super.
        Parameters:
        start - The starting point of the action.
        length - The length of the action.
        next - The next action.
        Returns:
        the next sub-task.

      • continueDividing

        protected abstract boolean continueDividing(long length)
        Determine whether the task should continue to divide or, instead, perform its computations. This method should, at least, make use of the static getSurplusQueuedTaskCount() method inherited from the RecursiveTask class, the result of which should generally be kept above 3 to maintain high concurrency.
        Parameters:
        length - The length of the action.
        Returns:
        true if it should continue dividing, false if it should perform its computations.

      • joinResults

        protected abstract T joinResults(T result1,
            T result2)
        Join the results of two sub-tasks.
        Parameters:
        result1 - The result of one task.
        result2 - The result of the other task.
        Returns:
        the result of joining result1 and result2.

        public T getResult()

      • getResult

        public T getResult(long timeout,
          java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit timeUnit)
        This method is the same as get(long,TimeUnit), except it wraps the declared exceptions in runtime exceptions.
        Parameters:
        timeout - The length of time to wait for the method to return.

        Returns:
